column5: I think it depends. My fiancÃ© remembers a lot of his delusions - however the ones that have been extremely severe and are classified as part of his psychotic break he has little to no memories of. He completely blacked out right before both of his hospitalizations, and thatâ€™s when his delusions were at their most severe (threatened to kill me, threatened to kill the president, thought I was replaced by a government issue robot etc). When I worked in a psychiatric hospital for teens, one of my patients had a psychotic disorder and it was the same situation. Sometimes he would remember his delusions in detail, other times he would have no memories of his behaviors or delusions ie: kicking another therapist in the face on my day off and then not understanding why she was bruised and had a broken nose the following week with no memory of the assault. This is just my experience though.
I just tried it - it didnâ€™t work ðŸ˜“

So I did check with mine (heâ€™s also my parentsâ€™) and he said he absolutely did not make that mistake and I qualify - that said when he gave me my taxes to sign and review in February he had accidentally put some of my little sisterâ€™s paperwork with my own and I had to rectify it so I donâ€™t totally trust him. My parents said Iâ€™m not claimed on the copy they got though.

Fingers crossed! It would definitely make things a lot easier. We donâ€™t have a cancellation policy and I have one client whose mother cancels a lot due to her being sick frequently so it would be great to still do sessions with her son remotely so heâ€™s not missing out.

I hope your senator is able to provide guidance! My fiancÃ© is in the middle of his SSID appeal but I know he did the non-filer get my payment and was told he would get the money but we havenâ€™t gotten it.

I think itâ€™s great that sheâ€™s trying to get the other cases doing at least partial telehealth. Iâ€™m lucky enough to have 19 hours a week right now (it was 29 but some of my younger cases couldnâ€™t handle the standard 3 hour sessions anymore) so Iâ€™m hoping because I still have 5 clients and telehealth overall seems to be working that theyâ€™ll allow for RBTs to continue telehealth. I know my clinical supervisor is hoping that because itâ€™s been so successful for us they will allow telehealth supervisions and telehealth appointments when an RBT is sick/contagious but able to work from home - so maybe thatâ€™s something insurance companies will consider too.

Hopefully they do! Iâ€™ve been supporting myself since I finished undergrad (although my parents are the â€œbankâ€ I have my loans taken out with for grad school - but Iâ€™m paying them back) - I checked with our tax accountant to make sure he hasnâ€™t been still filing my parentsâ€™ taxes listing me as a dependent and he says he isnâ€™t but Iâ€™m worried he made an error somewhere.
Me too - itâ€™s crazy
Iâ€™m so sorry. Itâ€™s so awful that so many of us are going through this.
I know exactly how you feel. Itâ€™s so scary. Iâ€™ve watched my bank account dwindle since March and Iâ€™m so worried about the upcoming months
Itâ€™s crazy. Iâ€™m hoping weâ€™re all able to receive our checks but at this point itâ€™s hard not to lose hope.
Thank you!

Thatâ€™s what Iâ€™m worried about too. How can you get the second check if youâ€™re not even getting your first? I hope youâ€™re able to find a job - I know itâ€™s hard out there. Iâ€™m lucky enough to be able to work from home (aba therapist) but took a pay cut thatâ€™s killing me.

I filed in the beginning of March - and Iâ€™ve tried every which way in the book. No capitals, with capitals, with condo number, without condo number just street address. It hasnâ€™t made a difference. We moved in mid March because our landlord died and her realtor son sold it out from under us with zero warning (thatâ€™s a whole other story...) and Iâ€™ve tried both with our old and new address. Still get the PSNA. FiancÃ© was able to file as a non-filer (heâ€™s disabled, waiting on SSI hearing) and got notice heâ€™d be getting a check at our new address.

I think at the end of the day you have to do whatâ€™s best for you and your son - whatever that may be. I actually have a client at my ABA practice who is in an extremely similar situation and ultimately he took the kids and left and the custody battle is nasty but itâ€™s been better for his and the kids mental health. That said, if Iâ€™ve learned anything from my own experience itâ€™s that nothing is permanent. I went from crying everyday and literally sleeping with a knife under my pillow for months just in case I needed it - and now weâ€™re at a point where weâ€™re able to just binge watch Marvel movies and play games together. Itâ€™s definitely not a â€œnormalâ€ relationship, but it is pleasant despite all the hardship that comes with it, and I wouldnâ€™t give it up. Also with the therapy - finding a therapist is like trying on shoes! A lot of people donâ€™t seem to realize this and think after a therapist or two if it didnâ€™t click or stick itâ€™s just â€œnot for themâ€. Iâ€™ve found (both working in a psych hospital, at an ABA practice, in grad school to become a clinical psychologist and personal experience) that therapy doesnâ€™t work properly until you find the right therapist. You can force yourself to see someone, the same way you can force your foot into a pair of shoes that isnâ€™t quite right, but youâ€™re not going to be comfortable. Try them on! Call a ton who specialize in family counseling - and you can probably find a niche who does family counseling for autism. If you call the number on the back of your insurance card theyâ€™ll give you a list of providers. Conduct phone interviews. They may be the â€œexpertâ€ but that doesnâ€™t make them the right fit. You have to try them on for size and sometimes it can take months to find the right person, but when you do it makes a difference. Based off your OP it sounds like your partner is the one rejecting therapy, if you do decide you want to continue your relationship, have her get involved interviewing candidates. A lot of people feel like they lose control because a therapist is providing advice they may not like or always agree with - by giving her some control over the process of finding the right person it may help.
Iâ€™m sorry youâ€™re going through that! My fiancÃ© did the non filer too and he hasnâ€™t gotten his check either and itâ€™s been weeks.

My state is starting phase 1 of opening on Wednesday the 20th - which is supposedly just restaurants for outdoor seating, hair dressers, malls and zoos/aquariums for outdoor only. I have one of my clientâ€™s mothers ask me daily when I can be in the home....none of my other clients seem to want me there or care about the fact that weâ€™re doing telehealth instead. Iâ€™ve asked my BCBA but she has no idea either and our clinical director has only said how much she loves telehealth so I have no idea when weâ€™re expected to go back. I definitely would not be comfortable doing so. I have a lung condition and an autoimmune disease, definitely not something I have any intention of doing any time soon. It seems like itâ€™s a total toss up in a lot of cases. I know phase 2 of reopening our state is at the end of June - so Iâ€™m guessing depending how phase 1 goes they may try and have us back in homes for June 20th. Our state still has 600 new cases coming a day on average so I donâ€™t see it going well.

Ugh itâ€™s so frustrating. Iâ€™m appreciative that itâ€™s supposedly going to come - but itâ€™s tough when you can barely make ends meet. My fiancÃ© canâ€™t work, heâ€™s disabled and waiting on an SSI hearing so itâ€™s just me trying to make ends meet on one income working 62 hours a week. That check would make things so much easier with the 20% pay cut I had to take.
I filed my taxes in March. No refund yet. No stimulus check yet. Payment status unavailable every time I check. I think itâ€™s just a waiting game at this point.

First, I can tell how hard youâ€™re trying and I think youâ€™re a really good parent. Iâ€™m an RBT - but Iâ€™m also a full time caregiver for my fiancÃ© who has schizophrenia, so I know being a full time caregiver is extremely hard. There was a point in time after his diagnosis when I really struggled - our extended family fell apart because they couldnâ€™t handle or accept his illness and I was absolutely miserable and suffering from PTSD from his psychotic breaks. Something my therapist told me was that â€œitâ€™s okay to grieve for the life you thought youâ€™d haveâ€. That simple phrase literally changed everything for me. I have been with my fiancÃ© since high school - and now Iâ€™m almost 25. We had all these plans, and now things are very different than I thought. It felt like this horrible thing, that was breaking me at the time, but thatâ€™s because I didnâ€™t grieve. Itâ€™s okay to feel the way youâ€™re feeling! This probably is not what you expected or planned for you, your partner, or your sonâ€™s life - and I think it would help if you let yourself really grieve it. One I took the time to grieve it I was able to push forward. My fiancÃ© is doing better, our relationship is a million times better, and our family is rebuilding their relationship with him after I told them to do the same grieving. I feel like giving yourself that grace to fall apart and really understand your grief may help you get some closure.
We havenâ€™t - I was planning on helping him do that tonight

I appreciate it - we live in CT. I called one in our state but theyâ€™re far away, and we have our first consult apt but not for several months. So if we could find an office available sooner it would be helpful.

BOOM Learning is my biggest asset. Iâ€™ve been doing telehealth since the beginning of March and I use it with the majority of my clients. You can make a free teacher account (although there is a premium you can pay for) and you can find free â€œdecksâ€ for everything from social skills to color ID. You can also create your own decks and customize them; then assign them to particular clients. I use this with an age span of literally 3-21.

Honestly because I used to work in a psych ward it didnâ€™t totally phase me because I was used to stuff like that, it more upset me that he was that far gone and didnâ€™t recognize me as myself v a robot version of me. Totally agree - there tend to be big differences in men and women. Heâ€™s put on some weight but Iâ€™m hoping heâ€™ll put on a little more! He totally wont, even if I fill them. Last time I did that Mountain Dew somehow wound up inside the organizer and the pills dissolved.....-___- my friend gave us a google nest as a gift and Iâ€™m setting it up right now actually so that I can send him reminders to do things even if I wasnâ€™t home so Iâ€™m hoping thatâ€™ll help since heâ€™s really into tech stuff.

Iâ€™m hoping heâ€™ll get consistent with it - I bought him a pill organizer and he left it unopened in his closet. The only reason heâ€™s even taking the antipsychotic anymore is because he threatened to kill me during a major psychotic break (and the president - secret service showed up, it was bad) and I told him Iâ€™m not willing to put myself in that kind of danger again so itâ€™s either take the meds or we need some time apart. Heâ€™s still in a place where he doesnâ€™t fully accept his illness and doesnâ€™t want to learn about it, so he relies on me and my knowledge to just anticipate his needs or find out the answers to questions he has. Iâ€™m working with him on coping skills and they have seemed to help a bit, but it takes a lot of prompting for him to use them, which is to be expected at this point. Iâ€™m hoping he puts on a little more weight. He was drinking Ensure and it was helping but now heâ€™s not. Heâ€™s eating much better though. Heâ€™s always been naturally thin but heâ€™s still about 20 pounds too shy. There are a lot of studies out there about nicotine and sz as well as caffeine actually. I really like this book Surviving Schizophrenja by E Fuller Torrey MD  - thereâ€™s a whole chapter on nicotine and caffeine addiction in correlation with schizophrenia. I bet you could easily find a free PDF of the chapter, itâ€™s like one of the better known books and specialists out there. No I donâ€™t mind at all! Heâ€™s on Zyprexa. The hospital wanted to switch him to a haldol and Zoloft cocktail since he wasnâ€™t taking either med - but now that heâ€™s taking the zyprexa he dropped it

My friendâ€™s husband has a psychotic disorder and is on a non habit forming ADD med and she said itâ€™s really helped him (heâ€™s got severe addiction issues), so Iâ€™m cautiously optimistic something like that may help but I want to be cautious in general. During his last hospitalization in September he tricked a nurse into giving him Ativan - which he hasnâ€™t touched in yeaaaaars (she shouldâ€™ve checked his chart.....but whatever), so Iâ€™m super cautious with him. The Wellbutrin so far hasnâ€™t made a ton of difference. He also doesnâ€™t take it regularly. He takes his antipsychotic religiously at this point because heâ€™s afraid of being hospitalized again - but not the Wellbutrin or his other optional sleeping pill/antidepressant. I think if he was willing to take it regularly it could help, but we also worry because it can trigger psychosis (I think thatâ€™s why he wonâ€™t take it consistently). I can totally see why cigarettes are soothing for the both of you. Iâ€™m in grad school to become a clinical psychologist and hope to specialize in psychotic disorders and have read a lot of studies about how common nicotine use is and how it can actually help - but he has lung issues and is severely underweight (refused to eat during the worst of his psychosis and dropped down to 86 pounds - and were hovering at 103 now....) so his doctor is trying to get him off of them. Right now he uses a vape pen and the patch on occasion. Iâ€™m so sorry you experience panic attacks with quitting thatâ€™s terrible and probably makes it so much harder.

That makes a lot of sense re the lawyer. Hopefully this office is willing to take him on. His psychiatrist wonâ€™t give him ADD medication - she thinks heâ€™ll abuse it because he had a problem abusing Ativan as a teen (granted this was before we even started dating so he was like 14... and now heâ€™s in his early 20s). She switched his anti depressant to Wellbutrin saying it would help (nope) and that it would help with him quitting smoking (another nope). Before covid I had found another psychiatrist who would take his state insurance after months of searching but he wonâ€™t do a consult until the shelter in place order is over, but Iâ€™m hoping he might have something in mind to at least help mitigate the severity of the ADD symptoms.

I will definitely update! So far I talked to his psychiatrist a little while ago and she said they sent the paperwork and got fax confirmation - so SSI â€œmustâ€™ve glitchedâ€ and â€œthey deny people all the time, just appeal itâ€. Iâ€™m going to help him with the process of appealing it when Iâ€™m done with appointments tonight. I also found the number of what seems to be a highly rated law office for SSI in our state so Iâ€™m going to try and reach them. You said it perfectly - itâ€™s all BS. He really struggles with the lack of motivation and the meds have made his ADD sooo much worse. He also has some tardive dyskinesia from the antipsychotic so he twitches in his legs for hours after he takes it so that makes it hard for him to do much

Oh thatâ€™s really good to know. I wouldnâ€™t be surprised if thatâ€™s contributing. Heâ€™s only been on the one antipsychotic but on the highest available dose - and was recommended a different one via injection but heâ€™s afraid of needles and wonâ€™t do it. Heâ€™s only tried two different antidepressants with it, and heâ€™s off anti anxiety meds because he abuses them. He literally only has that 4 weeks of work under his belt.

Thank you, and Iâ€™m sorry things have been hard for you guys too. Heâ€™s only been consistent with his medication since September, and while heâ€™s not having psychosis symptoms so much anymore, he still has the flat effect and lost most of his ability to function so like thereâ€™s just no way heâ€™s ready. What Iâ€™m learning from everyoneâ€™s responses is that this process seems really similar to workerâ€™s compensation where youâ€™re kind of dammed if you do and if you donâ€™t (in 2018 I worked in a psych ward and was assaulted and left with brain damage - so I canâ€™t work in those settings and it was a huge pay cut to transition from that to the type of therapy I do now). Workers comp wasnâ€™t sending checks, so I started doing this and then they were like BUT YOU CAN DO SOME WORK. Now theyâ€™re supposed to pay the wage gap and currently owe me 13,000 but at my hearing last week someone wasnâ€™t present so now we have to redo it next month after waiting a year since the last. I feel like while these institutions are meant to be helpful they kind of screw the people who need the most help. My fingers are crossed for you! I hope things turn around for you both soon.

I mean so far there hasnâ€™t been a single job recommendation but Iâ€™m really worried. Heâ€™s only ever worked 4 weeks in his life, and lost that position due to a major psychotic episode during a shift. Weâ€™re engaged and Iâ€™ve been financially supporting him on my own for years but with covid itâ€™s not viable anymore, Iâ€™m an ABA therapist and my patientâ€™s bail on their Telehealth appointments regularly because they donâ€™t take it as seriously so itâ€™s a huge pay cut, and hours are reduced throughout the practice anyways. Heâ€™s got so much in medical debt that Iâ€™ve been paying off for him for the last year but weâ€™re still not even close to paid off. Iâ€™m looking into attorneys now because Iâ€™m at such a loss. Iâ€™m sorry youâ€™re still going through all that, but youâ€™re not alone. It looks like this is sadly the norm for this.

Yea I think Iâ€™m going to have to. Heâ€™s been out of work for over 2 years. He canâ€™t even remember to use soap when he showers or stay awake more that 6 hours at a time. He canâ€™t be expected to work. If you have any recommendations for finding a good SSI lawyer please let me know.
It depends on the needs of the client and program youâ€™re running. My longest sessions pre covid were 3-4 hours 3x a week for one client, but the rest were 2 hours.

Oh so itâ€™s like workerâ€™s comp - that makes a lot of sense. I think we may wind up doing that then because I feel like weâ€™re in for a long road. Heâ€™s only been consistently taking his medication since the end of September. He can barely stay awake for 6 hours at a time let alone be expected to hold down a job.

Thatâ€™s what Iâ€™m afraid of. He hasnâ€™t worked since the beginning of 2018. I support both of us on one income and he had racked up thousands in medical debt for his hospitalizations that Iâ€™m still paying off for him. I canâ€™t afford to get him a lawyer I can barely keep us in our apartment. Iâ€™m sorry you had to go through all that!

Thank you! Seriously appreciate it. I called and spoke with the front office this morning and even though they have an office app that allows them to upload his records they wouldnâ€™t do it without me speaking with the psychiatrist, and left her a message to call me. She doesnâ€™t usually call back in these situations so I have a feeling Iâ€™ll be calling again tomorrow. It complicates things with the shelter in place order here and both he and I are immunocompromised so going there is going to be my last resort. Once you got your paperwork did things go smoothly? It was a shock to us - his case rep told us weâ€™d get a check next month and then we got this letter declining him.

I work over 30 hours of telehealth as an RBT right now. Some of the sessions with my youngest clients are shorter than they were in person - but the insurance companies have been very flexible and understanding that we need to reduce hours. Weâ€™re also doing supervision via telehealth. Itâ€™s honestly been pretty easy. Iâ€™ve been doing this since mid March with very few issues.

I work with a lot of older teens and early adults on the spectrum and those who are higher functioning are highly involved in their goals. Most of these guys really need work on social skills and executive functioning so we incorporate their goals for their futures as these particular clients have the ability to live on their own when the time comes. I think itâ€™s really important for them to be involved in their own treatment planning, even their IEP meetings at school.
That would be awesome!
Awesome thank you!
Thatâ€™s a great idea! Thank you!

I agree, and I think heâ€™d do well with something like that but itâ€™s not a behavior at home so Iâ€™m not sure how we could utilize it since heâ€™s no longer leaving the house. Mom just wants the behavior to stop - but heâ€™s about to age out and without the stimuli there heâ€™s not having the behavior. It would likely have to be something we teach mom as a parent goal (who is not very involved) and have her continue but since he ages out likely right around the time the shelter in place is lifted Iâ€™m not sure how effective it would be. Heâ€™s already lost access to visiting his brother, the sister in law doesnâ€™t want him in the home or around their daughter - but it doesnâ€™t seem to have been a deterrent. I canâ€™t even get an answer from mom on if this behavior happens when heâ€™s at school or when heâ€™s on school field trips (which there are apparently a lot of). I think my supervisor and I are missing a lot of information too so weâ€™re sitting down on zoom with his mom later to try and ask all these unanswered questions again so we can get a better understanding of what weâ€™re looking at.

Yea he understands that and is aware he needs to wait, and can verbalize it. But in the moment itâ€™s an impulsivity thing. He knows and can say and do all the right things at home but he canâ€™t control that impulse in public, and apparently the interventions used in the home are not working in public like reminding him to wait or ask for private time etc. I think some of it is attention seeking based on what weâ€™ve heard from all family members about how he behaves in public vs at home. Iâ€™ve worked with teens back when I worked in a psych hospital who needed similar interventions but theyâ€™re not easily generalized on a webcam. 

He just started with us. And ages out of the program in 3 months (weâ€™re in a hot spot state - weâ€™ve been told to expect to shelter in place until at least June). Mom wants a miracle which isnâ€™t going to happen, but weâ€™ve never even seen the behavior or physically been there in person because of covid. He has very low executive functioning skills and impulse control, but can understand abstract or difficult concepts and can practice these skills with ease and discuss them as long as heâ€™s not in the real life scenario it seems. We canâ€™t take him out with whatâ€™s going on in the world to even get baseline data.
My fiancÃ©â€™s psychosis almost always revolves around Jason Bourne to the point where the movies are banned in the house because itâ€™s an immediate trigger.

We use doxy.me and zoom since theyâ€™re compliant. Pinterest has a lot of resources for how to conduct telehealth online. Weâ€™ve been doing it for a few weeks here because we had one of the earliest shelter in place orders and itâ€™s really doable as long as youâ€™re flexible
I like the books by Ellen Hopkins - she has several, some about psych hospitalizations and the various mental illness the teens suffer there, some about depression, drug abuse etc

In CT we had to have certain guidelines changed by the state to allow RBTs to do telehealth - which they did, especially because this state has been a shelter in place lockdown state for awhile now. So the RBTs at my company - myself included - have been doing telehealth sessions. That said, lots of families have opted out of services, especially those with younger children because they donâ€™t want to help facilitate. There are also a ton of RBTs and BCBAs who donâ€™t want to do it either. Theyâ€™re just not working (granted a lot of them are the people who have duel income and do this as a job not necessarily needing the extra money or something). So Iâ€™ve been taking on other cases within my company who for whatever reason donâ€™t have a therapist working during quarantine. 

That said - the scheduling coordinator is already asking if Iâ€™ll keep these cases after this is over or just go back to my typical case load because of restaffing issues (Iâ€™ll be going back to my other part time job in the mornings once this is over) so theyâ€™re already stressing about in home and clinic services once this ends and having to redistribute cases. So I get why some of the companies youâ€™re contacting are saying you have to be willing to do the other options as well. I would clarify your stateâ€™s covid guidelines and regulations, and clarify with them on these calls what the expectations are during and after.
Thank you! We have to make it work somehow!

Itâ€™s a good activity - just filter the questions as you go instead of reading them on autopilot, I noticed a new update yesterday and some of the questions added were not socially appropriate given itâ€™s an app geared to kids (would you rather assault a police officer or gang member - literally one of the questions that pop up)

It really depends on their goals - one of my kiddos and I do social skill role playing and have packets of these scenarios that describe flexibility v rigidity type situations that heâ€™s been really enjoying. We also did a â€œbuild the perfect friendâ€ activity using the whiteboard in zoom where I had him list a minimum of 6 qualities heâ€™d want in his â€œidealâ€ friend - then re-examine those qualities in regards to being applicable to healthy friendships, and he liked that activity a lot too. I also have social skills card games we used to play in person that Iâ€™ve kind of altered to be compatible via telehealth whether itâ€™s getting a sibling or parent involved or just the two of us. Thereâ€™s an app called â€œeitherâ€ and itâ€™s silly scenarios like â€œwould you rather do x or yâ€ and I have one of my kiddos answer those but make them really think out and explain their answer to help them work on impulsivity and thatâ€™s gone well too.

The first comment on this post is absolutely spot on. I also recommend reading Milt Greekâ€™s blueprint for schizophrenia. Itâ€™s applicable to psychosis in general in a lot of ways and can teach you how to best support and understand him.

I think thatâ€™s what Iâ€™m going to have to do. Iâ€™m so frustrated by all of this. I canâ€™t wrap my head around what creeps theyâ€™ve been. I shouldnâ€™t be surprised though because theyâ€™ve done really weird stuff since their mom died. Right after she died I got home from work and someone had trashed the place. Squirted honey all over the walls. The door unlocked when I got there. My neighbor works from home and sees everything. I was able to find out exactly who did it and even had to write a letter telling them Iâ€™d contact the police if it happened again. I feel like these people are just nuts.
I needed this today, thank you
Doing it in CT. It can be tough with the little guys but my teenagers do great with it.

It depends on the program. Some state school masters level programs will let you, but a lot of rigorous programs require a previous psych program for your undergrad. My program only accepts previous psych students, and gives discounts/scholarship rates to those of us who also already work in the psych field outside of school.

My company is still open - and itâ€™s optional in home at this point. I also have an autoimmune disease and I voiced my concerns at the time and they brushed me off. Pretty much all the clients company wide cancelled so our company has offered telehealth services now. But it took losing business for that to happen, rather than two weeks of multiple employees asking.
The download of the counterfeit Bitsboard actually uses English in the app - but his mother speaks zero English so for her to work with him it has to be Spanish

He uses Bitsboard, the Endless Alphabet (and others in that series) app, Smart Shapes and Kahn kids but none of them appear in the google play store on the Spanish setting they have it on. I tried to download them for him so they could use it at home and only found something similar to Bitsboard except itâ€™s teaching incorrect information (like purple is beige and a square is a circle) so I donâ€™t want him using that. They have the Endless apps in Spanish but theyâ€™re not free and his mother wonâ€™t purchase them - I asked
I use that on my phone - it doesnâ€™t come up in google play in Spanish for free and she wonâ€™t purchase it

Unfortunately I think heâ€™d grow very bored of that. His attention span averages about 8 seconds without needing full physical prompting to be redirected to the task, so the apps he uses on my phone are set to a 2nd or 3rd grade level of spelling or shape recognition/colors because it keeps his attention.

Abcmouse is only free to teachers and since this is a Medicaid client (single parent with no job) thereâ€™s no way sheâ€™ll be willing to pay money to have access on his tablet. Iâ€™ll have her search the camp discovery app - maybe by his apt Tuesday itâ€™ll be back up!

Iâ€™m a therapeutic crisis intervention counselor, an ABA therapist and in grad school to become a clinical psychologist - any mental health workers with the mindset that mental health issues are due to people being broken are uneducated at best. Iâ€™ve had to take so many classes that talk about how health and mental health are perceptions within society, and that societal expectations are a huge part in the mental health system and diagnostic process. Yes chemical imbalances are very real - I have one and itâ€™s directly correlated with my anxiety disorder. And medication for individuals whose illness or thought processes become harmful to themselves or others is medically necessary - the same way someone with diabetes needs medication to protect themselves, my fiancÃ© needs antipsychotics so he doesnâ€™t become homicidal again. But as someone whose worked in psych hospitals, and works in a therapeutic practice now, medications can be given out like candy by certain individuals in the field - and so can diagnoses. Iâ€™ve seen people diagnose others with serious mental illnesses without psych testing, and then we do the testing and itâ€™s not accurate and itâ€™s a label a kid in the hospital has been trying to navigate for years. I think thereâ€™s a responsibility for professionals in this field to think rationally and responsibly and unfortunately that doesnâ€™t always happen. Nobody is broken because of any type of anxiety, or stress or emotion or chemical imbalance or trauma etc. you may feel things differently, experience them differently or process them differently but that doesnâ€™t have to be a bad thing. Why are there so many different math formulas people can use to solve the same problem? Itâ€™s the same thing. People are made with different formulas. Since my fiancÃ©â€™s diagnosis with a severe psychotic disorder people treat him like heâ€™s broken (his own psychiatrist made a comment along the lines of â€œno magic pill to fix himâ€ - were looking for a new one now) but the thing is, he doesnâ€™t need to be fixed, and heâ€™s not broken. He may not be able function on the same level that is socially normative in society (canâ€™t work right now, has trouble with executive functioning like remembering to brush teeth etc) but heâ€™s not broken. Heâ€™s the most kind, supportive and loving individual - but people see him looking disheveled on a bad day, or know his diagnosis (very public psychotic break) and ask really uneducated questions or make uneducated comments. I know this is kind of a rant - but my point is nobody is broken. Mental health issues are real, but the way society responds to them in the majority of cases is counter productive. Education breeds understanding and understanding breeds support. If these things were discussed more openly in society there would be a lot less people with the view that people suffering from any type of mental health disorder or struggle are â€œbrokenâ€. Societal views absolutely come into play, but theyâ€™re not the end all and be all or necessarily the cause of mental illness - but definitely effect how itâ€™s handled and seen.

Of course, if you ever need support youâ€™re welcome to PM me. Iâ€™d be surprised if they kept her less than 3 days, but here once youâ€™re admitted to the psych ward itâ€™s rare youâ€™re there less than 5 (on top of the 1-3 you spend in intake when you first arrive)

I understand where youâ€™re coming from - that said my company is a multistate establishment where it wouldnâ€™t effect them losing their company. I think you did the right thing by calling 911. Likely, if youâ€™re in the states, she canâ€™t be discharged for 72 hours. Attempts at jumping off the balcony are likely to be considered being a â€œdanger to herself or othersâ€ which means she has to be held on a 5150 psych hold. After the 72 hours theyâ€™ll do some evaluations, and if they think sheâ€™s still dangerous itâ€™ll become a 5250 where she can be held 2 weeks or more depending on the state, severity and laws. 

In regards to being put in a â€œfacilityâ€ - thatâ€™s where things get complicated. If sheâ€™s over 18 she canâ€™t be forced to go there unless sheâ€™s declared incompetent by a court of law. Some hospitals have 28 day or 3 month programs they may keep her for, but not if sheâ€™s no longer a danger to herself or others. And if you donâ€™t have money to put her into a private psych facility the odds are she wonâ€™t get in to a residential living facility if you tried. As someone who worked in one but for children - each of our patients had to have a minimum of 4 psychological hospitalizations longer than 3 days each, as well as other criteria. When my fiancÃ© had his biggest psychotic break pre medication he threatened to kill me, threatened to kill the president, had to be interviewed by the secret service and repeatedly told staff he was going to kill me after his hospitalization. No facility would take him. They told me he needed a minimum of 4 hospitalizations or multiple arrests plus hospitalizations. I know that likely isnâ€™t what you had hoped to hear but I want to be honest with you about what is common practice in my area (several states surrounding me have similar rules and laws). 

I would wait to see what happens with her current hospitalization. Theyâ€™ll start her on medications or adjust any sheâ€™s already on and try to get her stable. They also release with a treatment plan. So theyâ€™ll set her up with an appointment with her (or if she doesnâ€™t have one find her one) psychiatrist and likely a therapist.

Also totally depends. In the past I had a patient in a psych hospital who was a child with a psychotic disorder and it could last less than 25 minutes - or it would last weeks. With my fiancÃ© episodes lasted probably 3 days to 2 weeks average.

I think it depends on the situation and the individual. I donâ€™t leave my fiancÃ© alone when heâ€™s in psychosis but thatâ€™s because he typically gets homicidal tendencies. However, medicated, he hasnâ€™t had an episode since September
